deck: is a story arc for Rocket Raccoon's series.
description:
A Chasing tale is about somebody trying to pose as Rocket Raccoon killing people and destroying his reputation.

He is put behind bars but later escaped. This mysterious "raccoon" is also working with Amalya. A princess who Rocket rescued from a prison who tries to kill him later on.

On the "A Chasing Tale Part 4", Rocket Raccoon finally found out who the culprit was.

It was Blackjack O' Hare. Rocket Raccoon's old enemy dating back from Rocket Raccoon's first limited series.

In the end, Rocket Raccoon managed to fight his way out of Amalya's force and Blackjack O' Hare.
name: A Chasing Tale

issues.name: Phantom Year One: The Black Widow

deck: The ARMOR HUNTERS are coming! A relentless and surgical strike team from the farthest reaches of space – sworn to exterminate the X-O armor and all like it – have found their final target. They will hunt. They will trap. They will kill. And they will rid the universe of the X-O Manowar's incalculable destructive power... even if it means taking the Earth with it.
description:
Armor Hunters is an 19-issues crossover event featuring many of the Valiant characters and focusing on a group of alien warriors in pursuit of all powered armor, like the X-O Manowar Armor suit, with only one goal - to destroy it and its bearer!

Team

The main Armor Hunters team consists of squad leader Primary Reebo and members Helix (a digital being in physical form), Quartz (the muscle), Lilt (the adviser), GIN_GR (a giant robot that serves as operation center and spaceship), and formerly Mopp (the field technician). Not part of the actual team nonetheless trying to find the X-O armor on its own is the vicious alien humanoid Malgam, once host to the armor himself he is desperate to find and bond with it again.

Reading Order

Prelude to Armor Hunters

  • X-O Manowar #23-24 - Aric finds and figths Malgam on Earth's moon.
  • X-O Manowar #25 - Self-contained story called "The Armor Hunters in 'Burial'" focusing on the hunters exclusively and what they do. This story shows what happened before and after then end of #24.

Armor Hunters

The event begins with Armor Hunters #1 and the main story is told in the Armor Hunters mini-series. The story in X-O Manowar provides the backstory of the hunters themselves. The other three tie-ins are not necessary but provide extra information about the involvement of Unity, Bloodshot, and Harbinger, and help filling some gaps.

Recommended reading order:

  1. Armor Hunters #1
  2. Unity #8
  3. X-O Manowar #26
  4. Armor Hunters #2
  5. Unity #9
  6. Armor Hunters: Bloodshot #1
  7. Armor Hunters: Harbinger #1
  8. X-O Manowar #27
  9. Armor Hunters #3
  10. Unity #10
  11. Armor Hunters: Bloodshot #2
  12. Armor Hunters: Harbinger #2
  13. X-O Manowar #28
  14. Armor Hunters: Bloodshot #3
  15. Armor Hunters: Harbinger #3
  16. Unity #11
  17. Armor Hunters #4
  18. X-O Manowar #29*
  19. Armor Hunters: Aftermath #1

*There is an explicit note "Do Not Read Before Armor Hunters #4!"

Collected Editions

  • Armor Hunters (Armor Hunters #1-4, Armor Hunters: Aftermath #1)
  • Armor Hunters: Bloodshot (Armor Hunters: Bloodshot #1-3, Bloodshot #0*)
  • Armor Hunters: Deluxe Edition (Armor Hunters #1-4, Armor Hunters: Aftermath #1, Armor Hunters: Bloodshot #1-3, Armor Hunters: Harbinger #1-3, Unity #8-11, X-O Manowar #23-29, and 20+ pages of bonus content)
  • Armor Hunters: Harbinger (Armor Hunters: Harbinger #1-3, Harbinger Wars #1*)
  • Unity: Armor Hunters (Unity #8-11)
  • X-O Manowar: Prelude to Armor Hunters (X-O Manowar #23-25)
  • X-O Manowar: Armor Hunters (X-O Manowar #26-29)

Note: Issues marked with * are not part of the event.
name: Armor Hunters

deck: Grant Morrison's epic, redefining trip through the DC Multiverse.
description:
Overview

Shortly after the conclusion of the weekly series 52, writer Grant Morrison had planned to create a series with his fellow co-writers which focused entirely on the vast DC Multiverse they had set up within the pages of 52. The intended collaboration never gained any steam, but Morrison would continue to work solo with the idea for years, first mentioning it following the conclusion of his Final Crisis story arc. DC Comics first started to reveal details and art from Frank Quitely's issue in September 2012, but the series ultimately debuted nearly two years later in August 2014.

Like Morrison's previous work in Seven Soldiers of Victory, Multiversity would begin with a bookend chapter, setting up the entire story arc. Following the first issue, a series of seven monthly one-shots, each focusing on a specific parallel Earth would be released. Each of these one-shots could be read on their own, or skipped entirely, but a specific thread connecting all of them would be woven through out. After the release of the seven one-shots, a second bookend chapter would be released to close the series out.

Some of the industry's best artists would contribute to the series, many of whom had previously collaborated with Grant Morrison before like Frank Quitely, Cameron Stewart, Doug Mahnke, Chris Sprouse and Ben Oliver. Other artists who contributed to the series are Ivan Reis and more.
name: Multiversity

deck: Short story in three parts about The Dead Boy Detectives.
description:
This short story and arc was spread across three different anthology one-shots:

  • Part One: The Isle of Dogs (from Ghosts #1, released in October 2012),
  • Part Two: Let Slip the Dogs (Time Warp #1, May 2013), and
  • Part Three: Gone to the Dogs (The Witching Hour #1, October 2013).

Premise: The Dead Boy Detectives return and face a brand new enemy, Mr. Locke.
